required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Durability of Flexible Ureteroscopes and Causes of Infection During Flexible Ureterorenoscopy
clinical_study.official_title: Durability of Flexible Ureteroscopes and Causes of Infection During Flexible Ureterorenoscopy

lead_sponsor.agency: Clinical Research Office of the Endourological Society

clinical_study.source: Clinical Research Office of the Endourological Society

brief_summary.textblock: This is an observational study in which data on consecutive patients who undergo ureterorenoscopy with the use of a flexible ureterorenoscope are collected. In total 4 new ureteroscopes are used (2 from Olympus and 2 from Storz) to study the durability of the ureteroscopes and the possible microbiological load.

detailed_description.textblock:
This is an observational study in which data on consecutive patients who undergo ureterorenoscopy with the use of a flexible ureterorenoscope are collected. In total 4 new ureteroscopes are used (2 from Olympus and 2 from Storz) to study the durability of the ureteroscopes and the possible microbiological load.
Before the procedure is started the endoscope is tested for its microbiological load in two different ways:
Shake the tip of the flexible ureterorenoscope 5 seconds in a sterile container filled with 100 cc of NaCl 0.9% Using a well-fitting single use sterile brush or sponge brush the biopsy channel. Shake the brush during 5 seconds in a sterile container filled with 100 cc of NaCL 0.9%.
After the procedure is finished, the endoscope is tested for its microbiological load in two different ways:
Shake the tip of the flexible ureterorenoscope 5 seconds in a sterile container filled with 100 cc of NaCl 0.9% Using a well-fitting single use sterile brush or sponge brush the biopsy channel. Shake the brush during 5 seconds in a sterile container filled with 100 cc of NaCL 0.9%
Before dismissal of the hospital and at the first visit of the patient in the outpatient clinic:
Sample a urine culture and measure the temperature of the patient Mark and date the samples. Complete the lab form with all required information and the reason for sampling. Transfer all samples to the lab as soon as possible but at least within four hours after collecting the samples.
As for the clinical efficacy during each procedure a detailed questionnaire about the use of each ureteroscope is filled out. This includes the ease of use making mention on quality of the image, torque, flexibility and durability.
Data will be collected through electronic case report forms (eCFRs), with use of an online Data Management system (DMS).

primary_outcome.description: To evaluate the pre-operative microbiological load of the tip and the working channel of the most common used flexible ureteroscopes, after high level disinfection

secondary_outcome.description: To evaluate the durability of the most common used flexible ureteroscopes in terms of number of procedures, total use time and total degrees of flexibility loss until the first repair is needed.

To evaluate descriptive data on factors that may affect the durability of the flexible ureteroscopes. Factors measured are treatment time, treatment indication and anatomical location in the urinary tract, method of ureteroscope insertion number and type of accessory instrumentation through the working channel, difference in users, number of forcing the scope during the procedure and the number of disinfections.

study_pop.textblock: The study population compromises those patients of over eighteen years old diagnosed to undergo a ureterorenoscopy (diagnostic or therapeutic) with a flexible ureterorenoscope.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Patient presented with a diagnosis to undergo a ureterorenoscopy using a flexible ureterorenoscope
- over 18 years
- has signed informed consent
- the patient is being treated with the designated flexible ureterorenoscope
Exclusion Criteria:
- chronic urinary tract infection
- indwelling nefrodrain or JJ stent or bladder catheter.

overall_official.last_name: Jean de la Rosette, MD, PhD
overall_official.affiliation: Clinical Research Office of the Endourological Society
